page.title: 10An Inn in S.Clevedon & Kenn
page.content: The Drum & Monkey Inn at Kenn got its name when the son and daughter of two wealthy landowners were married. According to local custom their two coats of arms were combined. In one coat of arms there was a Tudor Rose and the other depicted a monkey. Many people thought the rose was a drum so when the two ere combined the result was the Drum and Monkey. In the last century the pub attracted a huge crowd, including the High Sherrif of Somerset. The occassion was the public execution of three men who had set fire to local haystacks. The pub is now very popular with tourists and locals. It has recently been refurbished. The original well under the pub has been restored and is now the focal point of the lounge. It is also said that the inn is haunted by a former landlady.
